conclusion: The shadows cast by the objects (cigarette pack, cigarette, egg, and alarm clock) are long and extend towards the bottom right of the image.
The light source is located relatively low and to the top left of the objects.
The length of the shadows is determined by the angle of the light rays; a lower light source creates longer shadows.
The direction of the shadows is opposite to the horizontal position of the light source; a light source to the left casts shadows to the right.
The light source moves 'to the right, directly above the objects,' meaning its horizontal position shifts to the right and its vertical position moves upwards.
When the light source moves higher, the angle of the light rays hitting the objects becomes steeper, resulting in shorter shadows.
The shadows will be cast directly downwards, appearing directly beneath the objects when the light source moves directly above.
Shadows A, B, C, and D will undergo the same changes in size and location based on the movement of the light source.
Shadows A, B, C, and D will become much shorter due to the light source moving higher.
Shadows A, B, C, and D will shift from extending towards the bottom right to being located directly beneath the respective objects.
The shadows A, B, C, and D will shift from their initial position to a new position located directly beneath the respective objects.
The shadows A, B, C, and D will become significantly shorter compared to their initial length.
